column1: CVE-2017-14937;The airbag detonation algorithm allows injury to passenger-car occupants via predictable Security Access (SA) data to the internal CAN bus (or the OBD connector). This affects the airbag control units (aka pyrotechnical control units or PCUs) of unspecified passenger vehicles manufactured in 2014 or later
column2: when the ignition is on and the speed is less than 6 km/h. Specifically
column3: there are only 256 possible key pairs
column4: and authentication attempts have no rate limit. In addition
column5: at least one manufacturer's interpretation of the ISO 26021 standard is that it must be possible to calculate the key directly (i.e.
column6: the other 255 key pairs must not be used). Exploitation would typically involve an attacker who has already gained access to the CAN bus
column7: and sends a crafted Unified Diagnostic Service (UDS) message to detonate the pyrotechnical charges
column8: resulting in the same passenger-injury risks as in any airbag deployment.;1.9;4.7;CWE-327 Use of a Broken or Risky Cryptographic Algorithm;The product uses a broken or risky cryptographic algorithm or protocol.;https://www.cvedetails.com/cwe-details/327/Use-of-a-Broken-or-Risky-Cryptographic-Algorithm.html;http://www.mmt.hs-karlsruhe.de/downloads/IEEM/Schwachstellen/PCU_Vulnerability_Description_HsKA.PDF

column1: CVE-2020-10281;This vulnerability applies to the Micro Air Vehicle Link (MAVLink) protocol and allows a remote attacker to gain access to sensitive information provided it has access to the communication medium. MAVLink is a header-based protocol that does not perform encryption to improve transfer (and reception speed) and efficiency by design. The increasing popularity of the protocol (used accross different autopilots) has led to its use in wired and wireless mediums through insecure communication channels exposing sensitive information to a remote attacker with ability to intercept network traffic.;5.0;7.5;CWE-319 Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information;The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.;https://www.cvedetails.com/cwe-details/319/Cleartext-Transmission-of-Sensitive-Information.html;https://docs.google.com/document/d/1XtbD0ORNkhZ8eKrsbSIZNLyg9sFRXMXbsR2mp37KbIg/edit;

CVE-2020-10282;The Micro Air Vehicle Link (MAVLink) protocol presents no authentication mechanism on its version 1.0 (nor authorization) whichs leads to a variety of attacks including identity spoofing
column2: unauthorized access
column3: PITM attacks and more. According to literature
column4: version 2.0 optionally allows for package signing which mitigates this flaw. Another source mentions that MAVLink 2.0 only provides a simple authentication system based on HMAC. This implies that the flying system overall should add the same symmetric key into all devices of network. If not the case
column5: this may cause a security issue
column6: that if one of the devices and its symmetric key are compromised
column7: the whole authentication system is not reliable.;7.5;9.8;CWE-306 Missing Authentication for Critical Function;The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.;https://www.cvedetails.com/cwe-details/306/Missing-Authentication-for-Critical-Function.html;https://github.com/rligocki/Diploma_thesis_px4;

column1: CVE-2020-10283;The Micro Air Vehicle Link (MAVLink) protocol presents authentication mechanisms on its version 2.0 however according to its documentation
column2: in order to maintain backwards compatibility
column3: GCS and autopilot negotiate the version via the AUTOPILOT_VERSION message. Since this negotiation depends on the answer
column4: an attacker may craft packages in a way that hints the autopilot to adopt version 1.0 of MAVLink for the communication. Given the lack of authentication capabilities in such version of MAVLink (refer to CVE-2020-10282)
column5: attackers may use this method to bypass authentication capabilities and interact with the autopilot directly.;7.5;9.8;CWE-288 Authentication Bypass Using an Alternate Path or Channel;A product requires authentication
column6: but the product has an alternate path or channel that does not require authentication.;https://www.cvedetails.com/cwe-details/288/Authentication-Bypass-Using-an-Alternate-Path-or-Channel.html;https://github.com/aliasrobotics/RVD/issues/3316;

column1: CVE-2021-46145;The keyfob subsystem in Honda Civic 2012 vehicles allows a replay attack for unlocking. This is related to a non-expiring rolling code and counter resynchronization.;2.9;5.3;CWE-294 Authentication Bypass by Capture-replay;A capture-replay flaw exists when the design of the product makes it possible for a malicious user to sniff network traffic and bypass authentication by replaying it to the server in question to the same effect as the original message (or with minor changes).;https://www.cvedetails.com/cwe-details/294/Authentication-Bypass-by-Capture-replay.html;http://starvlab.qianxin.com/?p=409

column1: CVE-2022-23126;TeslaMate before 1.25.1 (when using the default Docker configuration) allows attackers to open doors of Tesla vehicles
column2: start Keyless Driving
column3: and interfere with vehicle operation en route. This occurs because an attacker can leverage Grafana login access to obtain a token for Tesla API calls.;7.5;9.8;CWE-287 Improper Authentication;When an actor claims to have a given identity
column4: the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.;https://www.cvedetails.com/cwe-details/287/Improper-Authentication.html;https://github.com/adriankumpf/teslamate/commit/fff6915e7364f83b3030f980d5743299c4e5260d

column1: CVE-2022-27254;The remote keyless system on Honda Civic 2018 vehicles sends the same RF signal for each door-open request
column2: which allows for a replay attack
column3: a related issue to CVE-2019-20626.;2.9;5.3;CWE-294 Authentication Bypass by Capture-replay;A capture-replay flaw exists when the design of the product makes it possible for a malicious user to sniff network traffic and bypass authentication by replaying it to the server in question to the same effect as the original message (or with minor changes).;https://www.cvedetails.com/cwe-details/294/Authentication-Bypass-by-Capture-replay.html;https://drive.google.com/file/d/1MtmWfBs1r6Y3JN1HpbNsZqO1GcsdgPdc/view?usp=sharing

column1: CVE-2022-0878;Electric Vehicle (EV) commonly utilises the Combined Charging System (CCS) for DC rapid charging. To exchange important messages such as the State of Charge (SoC) with the Electric Vehicle Supply Equipment (EVSE) CCS uses a high-bandwidth IP link provided by the HomePlug Green PHY (HPGP) power-line communication (PLC) technology. The attack interrupts necessary control communication between the vehicle and charger
column2: causing charging sessions to abort. The attack can be conducted wirelessly from a distance using electromagnetic interference
column3: allowing individual vehicles or entire fleets to be disrupted simultaneously. In addition
column4: the attack can be mounted with off-the-shelf radio hardware and minimal technical knowledge. With a power budget of 1 W
column5: the attack is successful from around 47 m distance. The exploited behavior is a required part of the HomePlug Green PHY
column6: DIN 70121 & ISO 15118 standards and all known implementations exhibit it. In addition to electric cars
column8: airplanes and heavy duty vehicles utilising these standards.;3.3;6.5;CWE-306 Missing Authentication for Critical Function;The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.;https://www.cvedetails.com/cwe-details/306/Missing-Authentication-for-Critical-Function.html;https://www.brokenwire.fail/;

column1: CVE-2022-36945;The Remote Keyless Entry (RKE) receiving unit on certain Mazda vehicles through 2020 allows remote attackers to perform unlock operations and force a resynchronization after capturing three consecutive valid key-fob signals over the radio
column2: aka a RollBack attack. The attacker retains the ability to unlock indefinitely.;N/A;6.4;CWE-294 Authentication Bypass by Capture-replay;A capture-replay flaw exists when the design of the product makes it possible for a malicious user to sniff network traffic and bypass authentication by replaying it to the server in question to the same effect as the original message (or with minor changes).;https://www.cvedetails.com/cwe-details/294/Authentication-Bypass-by-Capture-replay.html;https://hackaday.com/2022/08/17/rollback-breaks-into-your-car/
column3: https://medium.com/codex/rollback-a-new-time-agnostic-replay-attack-against-the-automotive-remote-keyless-entry-systems-df5f99ba9490

column1: CVE-2022-37305;The Remote Keyless Entry (RKE) receiving unit on certain Honda vehicles through 2018 allows remote attackers to perform unlock operations and force a resynchronization after capturing five consecutive valid RKE signals over the radio

The attacker retains the ability to unlock indefinitely.;N/A;6.4;CWE-294 Authentication Bypass by Capture-replay;A capture-replay flaw exists when the design of the product makes it possible for a malicious user to sniff network traffic and bypass authentication by replaying it to the server in question to the same effect as the original message (or with minor changes).;https://www.cvedetails.com/cwe-details/294/Authentication-Bypass-by-Capture-replay.html;https://hackaday.com/2022/08/17/rollback-breaks-into-your-car/

column1: CVE-2022-39836;An issue was discovered in Connected Vehicle Systems Alliance (COVESA) dlt-daemon through 2.18.8. Due to a faulty DLT file parser
column2: a crafted DLT file that crashes the process can be created. This is due to missing validation checks. There is a heap-based buffer over-read of one byte.;N/A;5.5;CWE-125 Out-of-bounds Read;The product reads data past the end
column3: or before the beginning

column1: CVE-2023-26257;An issue was discovered in the Connected Vehicle Systems Alliance (COVESA formerly GENIVI) dlt-daemon through 2.18.8. Dynamic memory is not released after it is allocated in dlt-control-common.c.;N/A;7.5;CWE-401 Missing Release of Memory after Effective Lifetime;The product does not sufficiently track and release allocated memory after it has been used
column2: which slowly consumes remaining memory.;https://www.cvedetails.com/cwe-details/401/Missing-Release-of-Memory-after-Effective-Lifetime.html;https://github.com/COVESA/dlt-daemon/issues/440

column1: CVE-2022-3093;This vulnerability allows physical attackers to execute arbitrary code on affected Tesla vehicles. Authentication is not required to exploit this vulnerability. The specific flaw exists within the ice_updater update mechanism. The issue results from the lack of proper validation of user-supplied firmware. An attacker can leverage this vulnerability to execute code in the context of root. Was ZDI-CAN-17463.;N/A;6.4;CWE-367 Time-of-check Time-of-use (TOCTOU) Race Condition;The product checks the state of a resource before using that resource
column2: but the resource's state can change between the check and the use in a way that invalidates the results of the check. This can cause the product to perform invalid actions when the resource is in an unexpected state.;https://www.cvedetails.com/cwe-details/367/Time-of-check-Time-of-use-(TOCTOU)-Race-Condition.html;https://www.zerodayinitiative.com/advisories/ZDI-22-1188/;

column1: CVE-2022-42430;This vulnerability allows local attackers to escalate privileges on affected Tesla vehicles. An attacker must first obtain the ability to execute privileged code on the target system in order to exploit this vulnerability. The specific flaw exists within the handling of the wowlan_config data structure. The issue results from the lack of validating the existence of an object prior to performing operations on the object. An attacker can leverage this vulnerability to escalate privileges and execute arbitrary code in the context of root. Was ZDI-CAN-17543.;N/A;7.8;CWE-416 Use After Free;Referencing memory after it has been freed can cause a program to crash
column2: use unexpected values
column3: or execute code.;https://www.cvedetails.com/cwe-details/416/Use-After-Free.html;https://www.zerodayinitiative.com/advisories/ZDI-22-1406/;

column1: CVE-2022-42431;This vulnerability allows local attackers to escalate privileges on affected Tesla vehicles. An attacker must first obtain the ability to execute privileged code on the target system in order to exploit this vulnerability. The specific flaw exists within the bcmdhd driver. The issue results from the lack of proper validation of the length of user-supplied data prior to copying it to a buffer. An attacker can leverage this vulnerability to escalate privileges and execute arbitrary code in the context of root. Was ZDI-CAN-17544.;N/A;7.8;"CWE-120 Buffer Copy without Checking Size of Input ('Classic Buffer Overflow')";The product copies an input buffer to an output buffer without verifying that the size of the input buffer is less than the size of the output buffer
column2: leading to a buffer overflow.;"https://www.cvedetails.com/cwe-details/120/Buffer-Copy-without-Checking-Size-of-Input-('Classic-Buffer-Overflow').html";https://www.zerodayinitiative.com/advisories/ZDI-22-1407/;

column1: CVE-2023-29389;"Toyota RAV4 2021 vehicles automatically trust messages from other ECUs on a CAN bus
column2: which allows physically proximate attackers to drive a vehicle by accessing the control CAN bus after pulling the bumper away and reaching the headlight connector
column3: and then sending forged ""Key is validated"" messages via CAN Injection
column4: as exploited in the wild in (for example) July 2022.";N/A;6.8;"CWE-74 Improper Neutralization of Special Elements in Output Used by a Downstream Component ('Injection')";The product constructs all or part of a command
column6: or record using externally-influenced input from an upstream component
column7: but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify how it is parsed or interpreted when it is sent to a downstream component.;"https://www.cvedetails.com/cwe-details/74/Improper-Neutralization-of-Special-Elements-in-Output-Used-by-a-Downstream-Component-('Injection').html";https://kentindell.github.io/2023/04/03/can-injection/

column1: CVE-2023-26243;An issue was discovered in the Hyundai Gen5W_L in-vehicle infotainment system AE_E_PE_EUR.S5W_L001.001.211214. The decryption binary used to decrypt firmware files has an information leak that allows an attacker to read the AES key and initialization vector from memory. An attacker may exploit this to create custom firmware that may be installed in the IVI system. Then
column2: an attacker may be able to install a backdoor in the IVI system that may allow him to control it
column3: if it is connected to the Internet through Wi-Fi.;N/A;7.8;CWE-668 Exposure of Resource to Wrong Sphere;The product exposes a resource to the wrong control sphere
column4: providing unintended actors with inappropriate access to the resource.;https://www.cvedetails.com/cwe-details/668/Exposure-of-Resource-to-Wrong-Sphere.html;https://sowhat.iit.cnr.it

column1: CVE-2023-26244;An issue was discovered in the Hyundai Gen5W_L in-vehicle infotainment system AE_E_PE_EUR.S5W_L001.001.211214. The AppDMClient binary file
column2: which is used during the firmware installation process
column3: can be modified by an attacker to bypass the digital signature check of AppUpgrade and .lge.upgrade.xml files
column4: which are used during the firmware installation process. This indirectly allows an attacker to use a custom version of AppUpgrade and .lge.upgrade.xml files.;N/A;7.8;CWE-269 Improper Privilege Management;The product does not properly assign
column7: or check privileges for an actor
column8: creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.;https://www.cvedetails.com/cwe-details/269/Improper-Privilege-Management.html;https://sowhat.iit.cnr.it
